Graphical abstract This review summarizes the recent advances of screen printing, mainly focusing on ink formation, typical scalable applications, and challenging perspectives of screen printing for emerging printed microelectronics. Screen printing is regarded as a highly competitive manufacture technology for scalable and fast fabrication of printed microelectronics, owing to its advanced merits of low-cost, facile operability and scalability. However, its large-scale application in printed microelectronics is still limited by screen printing functional ink. In this review, we summarize the recent advances of ink formation, typical scalable applications, and challenging perspectives of screen printing for emerging printed microelectronics. Firstly, we introduce the major mechanism of screen printing and the formation of different organic- and aqueous-based inks by various solvents and binders. Next, we review the most widely used applications of screen printing technique in micro-batteries, micro-supercapacitors and micro-sensors, demonstrative of wide applicability. Finally, the perspectives and future challenges in the sight of screen printing are briefly discussed. Keywords Screen printing Ink Micro-batteries Micro-supercapacitors Micro-sensors 1 Introduction The rapid advancement on smart wearable and integrated electronics has largely stimulated the ever-increasing demand of printed microelectronics with light weight, high performance and outstanding mechanical flexibility [1–4]. Therefore, the printed microelectronics, such as micro-batteries (MBs), micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) and micro-sensors, required easy integration, high flexibility and ability to customize novel designs for specific applications [5]. For realizing the demand of flexible printed electronics, various printing technologies, such as screen printing [6–8], spray coating [9,10], inkjet printing [11–14], transfer printing [15,16], 3D printing [17–20], and 4D printing [21–23] have been well developed. Specifically, spray coating is a simple and low-cost strategy suitable to various component dispersions, but suffers from low printing resolution. Relatively, inkjet printing with high precision is widely applied in many fields [11–13,24–26]. Notwithstanding, the preparation of inkjet printing ink is very difficult due to the demand of low concentration of binders with a high viscosity that can prevent the blocking of nozzles of small-scale personalized ink-jet printer. Similarly, transfer printing could also realize high-resolution and large-area fabrication of MBs and MSCs, but its wide application is substantially limited by complex technique processes. 3D printing as another promising fabrication technology can realize freeform prototyping and construction. Especially, it can avoid the direct contact of squeeze nozzles to ensure free-pressure and is able to fully print the electrode and electrolyte for MBs, which can also infinitely increase the areal loading of printed devices. However, the increasing areal (mass) loading at the sacrifice of flexibility for wearable electronics. Progressing in the 3D printing, a more advanced 4D printing technology has been emerging due to its nature of intelligence by 3D printing on the smart materials, which can react to the stimulation of temperature, pressure, magnetism, water and so on. Therefore, 4D printing will have a revolutionary impact on a broad range of applications [27]. However, limited by the numbered smart materials, 4D printing technology has still large development room to meet the needs of common applications. Considering the flexibility and high areal loading of printed microscale energy storage devices, screen printing can realize the flexibly printing on various substrate and improve high areal loading by low-cost repeated printing process compared with spray coating and 3D printing. In addition, with the exploration of wide-range printable binders and solvents, screen printing can also realize an increasing precision compared with the inkjet printing and transfer printing, enabling it a promising technology for scalable fabrication of microelectronics. Screen printing, a simple operation by extruding the customized ink on the rigid or flexible substrates, centers on its low-cost, excellent operability, simple manufacture process and large-scale production, which has been applied on diverse applications [28]. The major challenge of large-scale applications for high-throughput fabrication fields ranging from batteries, supercapacitor and sensors is to prepare functional ink. Further, the eco-sustainable screen-printing technology is mainly dependent on “green-ink” by tuning the suitable binders and solvents [29]. Therefore, the aqueous screen-printing ink is more suitable for large-scale manufacturing of wearable microelectronics. So far, the commonly used solvents for printed ink are the water and organic solvents, while the binders are depended on the viscosity and functionality. The viscosity of the ink is related to the binder to ensure that the ink is firmly attached to the substrate without clogging the mesh of the screen fabric. In addition, the functionality of the binders is becoming more and more important for the formation of the ink. For example, in the graphene-based ink, the binders should contribute an electrostatic repulsion to avoid the easy aggregation of graphene nanosheets. Hence, the comprehensive consideration should be drawn for the excellent properties of screen-printing ink with appropriate rheological properties to apply alterable application requirements. Apart from the fabrication of the designed ink, screen printing allows a wide range of printing materials (e.g., particles, one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanotubes, two-dimensional (2D) materials) and optional substrates (e.g., paper, poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET), textiles, glass) [30–32]. Based on these appealing features, screen printing is widely applied for the rapid and scalable fabrication of microelectronics. As the rapid development of printed electronics in recent years [31,33–38], there are few reviews on screen printing to detailly introduce the fundamental of blade coating and summarize the preparation of ink components and key applications in different printed microelectronics. Herein we review the recent progress of ink formation, scalable applications, and challenging perspectives of screen printing for emerging printed microelectronics. Firstly, we systematically summarized the fundamental of screen printing, the rheological property of the inks influenced by the solvents and binders. Furthermore, we summarized the application of customized screen-printing ink in different printed micro-devices, such as MBs, MSCs, and micro-sensors (Fig. 1 ). Finally, the perspectives and future challenges of screen printing for printed microelectronics are highlighted, with a focus on a mission of flexibility, safety and intelligence. 2 Fundamental and ink formation of screen printing Among all printed fabrication methods for microelectronics devices, screen printing is known for its superiority of low cost, customizable pattern, excellent compatibility with flexible substrate and large-scale productions. However, the manufacturing parameters such as the rheology, printed resolution and film thickness, and ink composite including the fillers, binders and solvents of screen printing are rarely summarized. In this section, we will introduce the fundamental process and key components of screen printing in details. 2.1 The fundamental of screen printing The screen-printing process is mainly completed under the coordination of the screen fabric, squeegee, mesh, and ink. In a typical screen printing process, the screen stencil is firstly firmly fixed at the screen printing machine. Next, the ink is placed on one side of the printed pattern on the screen, and squeezed in virtue of the force of the squeegee onto the substrate. Finally, the desired pattern as same as variable mesh was readily formed (Fig. 2 ). Although screen printing is one of the most widely used printing techniques and its process is simple, the quality of printed films (e.g., resolution, adhesion to substrate, thickness) are determined by multiple factors. The patterning resolution is one of important properties of screen-printed films, which mainly depends on the numbers and materials (e.g., polyester fibers, stainless steel) of the meshes considering that the screen-printed patterns is the direct replication of meshes. In addition, it is also determined by the ink rheology to ensure high precision with fine edges through the mask without dispensing out the pre-patterned area. Apart from the resolution, the adhesion of printed films is influenced by surface tension and wettability of printable inks to targeted substrates, which could be adjusted by the used solvents and binders [30,33,34]. Besides, the thickness of printed films, as another significant factor, is up to the mesh number of screens, thickness of screen fabric and ink composition. In fact, the screens are prepared by a standardized production process, so there is no sufficient space to change the properties of screens. On basis of this, the research efforts in screen-printed film enhancement are mainly focused on ink modulation including active materials, solvents, binder and conductive additives, which will be discussed in detail as follows. 2.2 Screen-printed inks The ink for screen printing is typically composed of the fillers, binders and solvents, which can be coordinated in a suitable proportion to guarantee a proper viscosity that sometimes depends on the type of substrates, e.g., metals, wood, fabric, glasses, ceramics, polyethylene terephthalate, and paper [41,43]. One of the main challenges of printed microelectronics is the development of functional ink. However, the viscosity of screen-printing ink is mainly determined by the type and proportion of selected binders, which determines the ink rheological properties when printing at different substrates. At present, the binders are mainly divided into organic and aqueous binders. Taking into account of environmental protection, the aqueous binders have received extensive attention. Ink rheology is an important index to evaluate the performance of ink, which can be largely determined by the content of ink fillers, solvent ratio and binder types (Table 1 ). In addition, the physical and chemical stability of the ink is also affected by the different manufacturing methods and procedures, such as the temperature and time of stirring or dispersion [33,38]. 2.2.1 Composition of screen-printed inks The solvents play a core role for the rheological property of ink. So far, most screen printed inks select organic solvents (Table 1), such as toluene [40], tetrahydrofuran [44,68], dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) [45], N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) [46–48], DMF [49], propylene glycol [50], glycol [51], 2-propanol [52], and ethanol [40,53], which are volatile, poisonous, and environmentally unfriendly, preventing the wide application for wearable electronics. Toluene was selected as the polystyrene-block-polyisoprene-block-polystyrene (SIS) solvent due to its similar Hillenbrand solubility parameters [40]. The NMP [46–48] has become an extensively applied solvent for the preparation of ink due to its low volatility, good thermal and chemical stability and excellent compatibility with most organic and inorganic compounds. For instance, the NMP is combined with tetrahydrofuran as a solvent to construct the silver and graphene ink [44,68]. However, with the sustainable development and green initiatives, these organic solvents are not the best choice for ink preparation due to its toxicity and non-environmental friendliness. Hence, it is very urgent to find a “green solvent” that can not only achieve high solubility and stability of fillers, but also meet the needs of health and environment. Recently, great efforts have been devoted to explore potential and multifunctional solvent substitutes, such as deionized water [7,56–64] and bio-based solvents [54,55]. Accordingly, dihydrolevoglucosenone (Cyrene) with non-toxic and friendly to human health [39,48] was reported as a potential replacement for organic solvent of NMP (Fig. 3 a). Especially for the ultrahigh concentration of graphene screen-printing ink, the Cyrene provided a better dispersion and a lower risk of structural damage of graphene under continuously ultrasonic process compared to NMP solvent (Fig. 3b) [39]. It also can be specially demonstrated by the Raman spectroscopy results (Fig. 3c). Further, Costa et al. developed a solvent of N,N’-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU) with excellent chemical stability and superb dissolving ability to many organic and inorganic compounds and even some polymers for printing ink. The rheological properties of the ink were compared with the ones with the conventional solvent NMP, indicating a more pronounced shear-thinning behavior than the NMP ink (Fig. 3d) [67]. Additionally, the terpinol has the advantages of low curing point (−40 ℃), high boiling point (217 ℃), natural composition, colorless and tunable viscosity, regarding as a green-health solvent for graphene ink and Pb3O4 ink (Fig. 3e) [54,55]. Considering the unfriendly to health for low toxicity organic solvents, deionized water [7,56–64] with the nature of high-level safety has been considered a promising ink solvent in the future. For instance, Yu et al. reported a MXene ink using deionized water as the solvent for the fabrication of MXene based MSCs via screen printing technology (Fig. 3f). The MXene ink exhibits a shear-thinning behavior in which the viscosity decreases with increasing shear rates, and the ink possesses high viscosity of >104 Pa s at a shear rate of 0.05 s−1 (Fig. 3h). In addition, according to the curves of storage modulus (G′) and loss modulus (G″) of the ink, as well as the oscillatory frequency sweep results (Fig. 3i and j), it is indicated that the MXene-N ink can flow continuously on various substrates and be printed with the well-defined patterns (Fig. 3g) [7]. This result provided a distinctive insight to harnessing such green-health solvent of deionized water into the printable ink with superior rheological property. Apart from the solvents, the binders play an important role in the screen-printed inks. The appropriate binder can ensure that the ink is fluently printed on different complex substrates. So far, according to different application needs, organic-based and water-based binders have been widely studied. Polymeric materials, such as the SIS [40], polycarbonate (PC) [49,68], and thermoplastic polyurethane polymer (TPU) [44], Nafion [52], polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [46,47] and PTFE binder [53] have been commonly used as the binders for screen printing technology to realize functional properties during the adjustment of proper adhesion of the ink. This section will be covered in detail in the next section. To further improve the electrical conductivity of the ink, conductive additives, such as carbon black [47,56,63], acetylene black [58], graphite [64] and carbon nanotubes [52,65,66], are commonly used. Typically, for some non-metallic inks, graphene is widely applied in the preparation of screen-printing ink due to its high electrical conductivity and 2D laminated structure to produce a planar conductive network to improve the electrical conductivity of microelectronics [53]. Further, in order to form a highly conductive network, 1D carbon nanotubes combined with 2D graphene served as a high conductive bridge to conduct a three-dimensional conductive network, which can together enhance the conductivity of the printed microelectronics [65,66]. For some metallic inks, graphene is usually selected as a conductive additive to connect metal particles and achieve better printing effects [57]. In addition, active materials are mainly divided into battery materials, sensing materials and conductive carbon materials according to different applications. 2.2.2 Organic screen-printed inks For organic screen-printed inks, the choice of the binder is crucial. Due to the special molecular chain structure of organic binder, much attention has been paid in some special fields. In particular, owing to the unique block polymeric structure of short polystyrene terminal ends and long polyisoprene chain which can lead to the cross-linking under high temperature, the SIS has superior elasticity and mechanical strength, as well as excellent flexibility at low temperature of −65 °C. Benefiting from the unrivaled properties of SIS, a stretchable Zn-Ag2O battery exhibited attractive hyperelastic properties (≈1300% elongation). Based on the superiority of SIS, the stretchable batteries still maintained the prominent electrochemical and mechanical properties (Fig. 4 a and b) [40]. On the other hand, the organic binders have special functions, especially used in the ink of lamellar structural materials. For example, PC as an organic binder characteristic of functional polymer chains has been utilized in preparing hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) ink. This functional chain of polymer macromolecules adsorbed on the lamellar materials by means of steric hindrance effect to enable the lamellar materials dispersing well. Therefore, the PC polymer prevented further aggregation of the lamellar h-BN materials during centrifuging at a higher viscosity, resulting in a shear-thinning behavior for h-BN ink (Fig. 4c-f) [49]. Also, TPU with high optical transparency, excellent mechanical strength, and good solubility in various organic solvents was selected as the binders to produce the viscoelastic ink for wearable electronics [44]. In addition, the PVDF with the merits of high impact toughness, corrosion resistance and adjustable viscoelasticity was widely applied to the manufacture of conductive carbon ink printed as a carbon-based current collector [46] or an electrode ink [47]. Nafion, depending on excellent thermal and chemical stability, as well as mechanical strength, has been applied for a screen-printed cathode for nonaqueous Li-O2 batteries. It is noted that Nafion is firstly lithiated by using lithium hydroxide aqueous solution to fabricate the cathode ink. The lithiated Nafion ionomer owns a stronger crosslinking due to the interaction between the Li ion and hydrogen in the sulfonate group of Nafion [52]. As we known, a binder is usually added to the ink, which has a certain adhesion to ensure that the ink can be firmly printed on the substrate. For example, it is very unfavorable to the preparation of graphene ink, owing to the restacking and aggregation of graphene nanosheets. To solve this problem, Hu et al. ingeniously selected cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB) as a binder into the graphene ink, which can stabilize the ink by the electrostatic repulsion between graphene and CAB molecules (Fig. 4g-i) [48]. In addition, considering the graphene deposition and green-sustainable, Wang et al. chose a bio-based polymer, carboxymethylcellulose sodium salt (CMC) to prevent the aggregation of graphene nanosheets [61]. In addition, another bio-based polymer, chitosan has a variety of physical and chemical functions, such as biodegradability, biocompatibility, and non-toxicity, which enables it a potential binder candidate for printed electronics. By applying chitosan as binder, activated carbon (AC) ink was synthesized to fabricate screen-printed aqueous supercapacitors with high stability and operatable voltage [60]. 2.2.3 Aqueous screen-printed inks Taking into account of the green sustainable development, human health, and environmentally friendly in the screen-printing post-processing process, the aqueous binders, possessing the merits of low cost and environmentally friendliness, are considered as the most ideal candidate. Usually, it is relatively common that adding binders is to enhance the adhesion in the preparation of inks. However, the effect of binders on electrical conductivity should be emphasized. Practically, the addition of binders is usually not conducive to the improvement of ink conductivity, or even negatively related to electrical conductivity [48]. To overcome this problem, Nørgaard et al. presented a reliable approach for printing ink by adding mildly oxidized graphite (mGO) into polymeric binder of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) that have not destroyed the electrical conductivity of ink. Meanwhile, the sheet-resistances (R S) can be enhanced by two orders of magnitude under compression (Fig. 5 a) [54]. Hence, this aqueous binder has a certain contribution to the improvement of electronic conductivity. As a water-dispersible binder, the viscosity can be easily adjusted by changing the proportion of water, the monomer structure and molecular weight of aqueous binders [45]. An aqueous binder of PSS can achieve a high viscosity by adjusting the monomer concentration and molecular weight of PSS. In addition, PSS can also realize the good dispersion of various materials and uniform anchoring through electrostatic repulsion interactions by virtue of its sufficient sulfonate groups (-SO3-). Accordingly, PSS was selected as a polymeric binder to construct a PEDOT:PSS/graphene ink to improve the charge-transport performance and viscosity. Notably, this binder allows stable dispersion of nanoparticles and graphene in an aqueous PEDOT:PSS ink through electrostatic stabilization. Therefore, PSS is a promising polymeric binder for optimizing the viscosity of PEDOT:PSS solution to realize the homogeneous printing on various flexible substrates (Fig. 5b) [45]. Apart from the tunable viscosity, the binders should also be versatile, enabling the reduction of graphene and strong bonding of graphene to the binders. However, graphene ink requires harsh post-treatments owing to the low electrical conductivity of GO, which restricts GO as a substrate for widely application. Recently, Gao et al. reported that butane tetracarboxylic acid (BTCA) and sodium hypophosphite (SHP) were applied to reduce GO and establish a tenacious chemical bond between reduced GO (rGO) and viscose fibers after the screen-printing process (Fig. 5c). Interestingly, the depth of fabric penetration and GO states were also tuned through the control of the concentration of GO ink, resulting in higher viscosity of GO ink with low penetration depth (Fig. 5d). Further, these nonwoven fabrics printed by rGO ink exhibited high electrical conductivity when applying to physical sensors [69]. This approach not only achieved GO reduction through a simple printing process by adding special reagents, but also strongly adhered the ink to the fabric, which was worthy of further promotion for printed microelectronics. Necessarily, the binder's transparency and high viscoelasticity are of great importance for printed electronics. For instance, Pei and co-workers reported highly conductive Ag nanowires (AgNWs) ink composed of hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, antifoaming agent and fluorosurfactant (Fig. 5e). Further, the fluorosurfactant served as a regulator of surface tension of ink to promote the adhesive ability of ink to the printing substrates. Also, hydroxypropyl methylcellulose as a viscoelastic polymer with high transparency and stable performance can provide thixotropic behavior for the ink. Besides, distilled water in this work was selected as a “green” solvent due to its environmental friendliness and low cost. All the features of this water-based AgNWs ink produced a shear-thinning thixotropic behavior for three ink distinguished by the AgNWs solid contents (Fig. 5f and g) [50]. In addition, due to the high transparency and stable performance of hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, it is very popular in AgNWs ink. Recently, a screen-printable AgNWs ink with high conductivity (up to 8.32 × 103 S cm−1) by selecting hydroxypropyl methylcellulose as binder was reported by Lai et al. [59]. It is noted that the AgNWs ink possessed suitable rheological behaviors and showed high resolution (100 µm) and favorable optical transmittance (≈80%) when screen printed on flexible substrate. To adapt to the eco-environmental requirements, the ink of screen printing plays a crucial role in the manufacturing of printed products. Recently, waterborne polyurethane reported by Zhang et al. [62] is a safe, reliable and environment-friendly polymer material with excellent mechanical properties and compatibility. What’s more, the viscosity of waterborne polyurethane is generally adjusted by water-soluble thickeners and water. Due to its health and environmentally friendly properties, the ink can be well used in many fields. Specifically, Zhang et al. proposed a polyethyleneimine graphene-modified surface-tailored graphene (PEI-rGO) ink utilizing waterborne polyurethane to achieve scalable manufacturing of screen printing (Fig. 5h). Apart from the waterborne polyurethane, waterborne resin [56], LA132 binder [7] and polyacrylic latex [58] have been got attention due to the superiority of easily soluble in water, low toxicity, and environmentally friendliness. 3 Screen-printed microelectronics 3.1 Screen-printed micro-batteries The sustainable development of flexible energy storage devices requires a high-safe energy supply and low-cost fabrication technology. The commonly used manufacturing methods, such as 3D printing and photolithography, have provoked tremendous development of MBs in the past few years, but their commercial applications were still limited by high cost, rigorous technical and equipment requirement, as well as complicated manufacturing process. Screen printing is cost-effective, processable flexibility and easy operation. Therefore, it has been applied for the fabrication of various MBs (Table 2 ), such as Zn-Ag2O batteries [40], lithium-ion micro-batteries (LIMBs) [47,63,64,67,70–74,78], Zn/Ag battery [46,75], and Zn/MnO2 battery [43]. Furthermore, screen printing technology has been extended to produce printable electrolyte membranes and all-solid-state batteries. So far, various positive electrode materials have been exploited for screen printing LIMBs, such as LiCoO2 [71–74], LiMn2O4 [78], lithium metal phosphates (LiFePO4, LiMnPO4 and LiCoPO4) [47,63,67], and vanadium oxides [79]. The active materials with different size and morphology make an impact on the thickness of screen-printed MBs. The larger active material particles will increase the thickness of MBs and need a larger mesh of printing screen, which directly affected the long-range dynamics of Li ion migration, resulting in low specific capacity of the cell. Also, the porosity of the active material ink will affect the performance of printed MBs by influencing the adhesion and exfoliation of active materials. Recently, the printable ink has been conducted for aqueous Zn//MnO2 MBs and LIMBs by screen printing. An aqueous printable Zn//MnO2 MBs with characteristic of high-safety, prominent flexibility, and excellent performance has been reported by Wang et al. [43]. The printable aqueous Zn//MnO2 MBs with an interdigital microelectrode design delivered a notable volumetric capacity of 19.3 mAh cm−3 at 7.5 mA cm−3 (Fig. 6 a and b). Moreover, MXene-based LIMBs have been fabricated by printing aqueous-based ink, which are combined MXene and electrode materials of lithium titanium oxide (LTO) as anode and lithium iron phosphate (LFP) as cathode in the interdigital planar geometry to realize an interbedded structure interlining lamellar MXene and electrode particles (Fig. 6c and d). The printable LIMBs offered a high areal energy density of 88 μAh cm−2 at a current density of 20 μA cm−2 (Fig. 6e) [41]. Based on the excellent electrochemical performance of these printable MBs, screen printing technology will open a new avenue to facilitate the environmentally friendly and high-safe MBs. Apart from the Zn//MnO2 MBs and LIMBs, the flexible nickel-metal hydride (NiMH) battery has been also fabricated by screen printing [77]. To improve electrochemical performance of the flexible NiMH battery, the fabrication of a flexible and poriferous nickel matrix is the prerequisite. In order to obtain the porous structure of nickel, flexible porous nickel matrix has been firstly printed on the steel sheets using an insulating ink before nickel electrodepositing on this insulating template (Fig. 6f). Profiting from the novel manufacturing method of porous structure by screen printing, flexible NiMH batteries displayed excellent energy density of 151.8 Wh kg−1, demonstrating the promise of screen printing in application of NiMH batteries (Fig. 6g). Besides, two stretchable Zn-Ag2O battery with a “NANO” design has been manufactured using screen printing technology by a customize Zn/Ag2O ink selected SIS as a binder (Fig. 7 a). It is observed that the strain mapping showing a significant difference when the rectangular carbon electrodes (1:3 ratio) is stretched from 0% to 100% stretching (Fig. 7b, c). Obviously, the pristine battery shows a discharge capacity of 3.78 mA h cm−2, and the stretching battery slightly increases by 3.94 mA h cm−2 whereas the average voltage decreases slightly after stretching. The increased capacity is ascribed to the enlarged active surface area after stretching, while the decreased voltage is caused by ascribed to the increased polarization (Fig. 7d). Remarkably, the prominent mechanical properties of the SIS binder enable the Zn-Ag2O battery an outstanding flexibility, which can resist a severe tension and present a high capacity of 2.5 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 7e) [40]. Screen printing technology can print on flexible substrates to realize excellent flexibility and electrochemical properties, which is respected a promising candidate for flexible microelectronics. The screen printing technology has been also applied for thin-film Li-ion battery. A pouch-type flexible thin-film Li-ion battery is designed by sequentially screen-printing the current collector, cathode, anode and gel polymer electrolyte (Fig. 7f). This interesting thin-film Li-ion battery using dry-wet processes exhibits an energy density of 332.8 Wh L−1 based on metallic of Al and Cu as the current collector (Fig. 7g) and high capacity retention of 84% after 50th cycles. The flexibility is also evaluated by considering the fluctuation of open-circuit voltage, resulting in a stable fluctuation under the state of folding, bending and stretching (Fig. 7h). The high capacity and flexibility enable the feasible and predominant screen printing technology a promising strategy for promoting the development of thin-film lithium-ion battery [74]. Besides, screen printing is a low-cost, easy-to-operate manufacturing technology for MBs with thick film electrode. In terms of these characters, Lee et al. reported Zr-doped LiCoO2 thick films up to 20 μm by a screen-printing process [70]. In order to attain high energy density, both of the thick and smooth surface for screen-printed LiCoO2 films should be considered synchronously. The rougher the surface, the greater the risk of an electrochemical short circuit. However, the annealing process may cause an uncontrolled structure of the printed electrode hole and increase the surface roughness of the films. Based on the drawbacks, Park and coworkers propose a strategy to manufacture the LiCoO2 thick film without a post-annealing process. The LiCoO2 powder is coated with a carbon layer by pyrolysis of the mixture of resorcinol and carbon black, which can reduce the surface roughness of the printed film and then obtain excellent performance with high discharge capacity of 179 μAh cm−2 [71]. Also, an all-solid-state Li ion battery with greater energy density can be achieved by a screen-printing process. This all-solid-state lithium ion battery selected Nb-doped Li7La3Zr2O12 and Li3BO3 as a solid-state electrolyte by annealing, which present better excellent performance than the traditional liquid electrolyte. Traditional solid-state batteries have the drawback of large contact interface impedance between electrode and solid electrolyte. However, the tighter bonding between solid-state electrolyte and cathode can be efficiently realized by screen printing combined with the later calcination process, thereby reducing the surface impedance [73]. 3.2 Screen-printed micro-supercapacitors Due to the merits of fast charge and discharge capability, high output power, long cycle life, easy production and integration, MSCs have great potential as an on-chip microscale energy storage unit. Furthermore, MSCs can be used as a supplement to battery and energy collection system and a microscale power supply for next-generation flexible on-chip electronic products [82–85]. High performance-price ratio and high-throughput processing method for large-scale production of electrode materials are crucial for the wide application of MSCs. To this purpose, screen printing has been extensively exploited in the production of planar MSCs because of its inherent simplicity, good repeatability and high compatibility with various functional ink and substrates [86–88]. Compared with the traditional sandwich structure, the interdigitated planar MSCs provides several orders of magnitude higher power density than batteries, so it is easy to be integrated into miniaturized electronics for nano-/micro-level power source. In order to realize the printable potential of supercapacitors on an industrial scale, a cheap thin-film electrode production process is highly needed. In general, screen printing is one of the most extensive and significant industrial printing technologies for thin-film manufacturing. Most interestingly, the MSCs produced by screen printing can be designed to display the required aesthetic characteristics [8,80,81,89], for example, parallel strip, interdigital, circular interdigital, and concentric circle shapes (Fig. 8 a) [80]. By designing a variety of line gap and shape patterns, hundreds or thousands of high-resolution MSCs with conductive tracks and letters can be printed quickly in a matter of seconds (Fig. 8i) [90]. As a feasible manufacturing process, the development of high quality and high conductive material ink is very important for screen printing MSCs. A promising conductive ink should have good printing performance, long-time stability, low cost and compatibility with diverse substrates, flexibility and tensile strain resistance. To prevent the ink penetration and remain structural integrity, screen-printed inks should possess high viscosity and elasticity to assure its thixotropy and solid-like behavior. Typically, graphene has high intrinsic conductivity, good mechanical property, and expandable production capacity, making it a promising conductive and electrode material for the formation of ink [53,80,91]. For example, using highly-conducting graphene ink, Wu et al. [80] directly screen printed customized and integrated MSCs with designable shapes and size on any substrates, which efficiently improved the working voltage and capacitance of MSCs through series or parallel connection. Notably, an energy storage pack with the serially connected 130 MSCs was capable of outputting a record voltage over 100 V (Fig. 8b). The screen-printed graphene based MSCs can offer a high areal capacitance (1.324 mF cm−2) and large volumetric capacitance (0.490 F cm−3), and remain stable electrochemical performance after hundreds of cycles (Fig. 8f and g) [81]. Besides, the screen-printed graphene patterns also serve as the current collector for MSCs [92]. Further, screen-printing is developed for the construction of asymmetric MSCs based on ultrathin MnO2 nanosheets as positive electrode and graphene as negative electrode, achieving excellent flexibility and electrochemical performance, for example, a high energy density (97.2 Wh kg−1) with capacitance loss less than 3% after 10,000 cycles [89]. Additionally, graphene has been used as the conductive network to carry active polymer materials and formulate mixture ink, showing the industrial applicability of screen printing technology in the manufacture of MSC electrodes [53]. The voltage of single-cell VN//MnO2 asymmetric MSCs comprising of VN and MnO2 interdigitated electrodes through a sequential screen-printing method achieved a high voltage of 2.2 V, comparable to the most reported in-plane MSCs and asymmetric MSCs [93]. Further, the MSCs via connection of two cells in series can expand the output voltage to 4.4 V, twice of single device. At the same time, by using parallel mode of two cells, the capacitance can be doubled easily, which provides an advanced modulation mode for device integration. The main challenge of screen printing is to prepare printable ink with suitable viscosity and rheological properties. In the most cases, it is highly necessary to use inactive additives to prepare electrode materials for printable ink, which will adversely impact on the functional properties of MSCs [8,94]. More recently, Liang et al. [57,95] developed the thixotropic ternary nano composite-based printable ink containing 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, and 2D nanosheets, which enables them to make a viscous and colloidal ink without additional inactive additive. Besides, the screen-printed MSCs from MXene composite ink without any inactive additives exhibit high volumetric capacitances (864.2 F cm−3), outstanding rate capability (304.0 F cm−3), excellent power density (48.5 W cm−3) and energy density (13.5 mWh cm−3), and ultralong cycle life (90% retention after 10,000 cycles) [95]. Interestingly, Zhang et al. [8] reported an extensible screen-printing additive-free 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene aqueous ink with appropriate rheological properties (Fig. 8h). The MSCs based on MXene sediment ink present excellent areal capacitance of 158 mF cm−2 and energy density of 1.64 µWh cm−2. These MSCs could be facilely connected in series or parallel to boost the output voltage and capacitance (Fig. 8c-e, i-l), and to construct integrated MSCs to meet specific energy/power needs (Fig. 8j). In the process of screen printing, the influence of the self-stacking problem of 2D material ink on the performance of MSCs is also considered. To address the self-stacking, Yang et al. [96] developed a 3D boron carbon nitride (BCN) microsphere ink as electrodes of MSCs. The areal capacitance of a single MSC reached 41.6 mF cm−2. The MSC also exhibited a remarkable mechanical flexibility without obvious capacitance decay even upon bending to 180°. Recently, the manganese hexacyanoferrate(MnHCF)-MnOx-based ink, in which MnOx with hydrangea-like structure grown on MnHCF nanocubes, was formulated to produce the flexible MSCs [97]. Besides, different MSCs have been designed and fabricated by screen printing diverse functional inks such as 3D-network graphene/CoS2/Ni3S4(G/CoS2/Ni3S4) ink [98], amorphous FeOOH/MnO2 ink [58], and nanoporous SnO2/CNT ink [99]. Due to the rapid development of screen-printed inks and the advantages of screen-printing technology, screen-printed MSCs are anticipated as miniaturized energy-storage device, which can serve as a micro-power source for self-powered, wearable and foldable microelectronics. 3.3 Screen-printed micro-sensors Apart from MBs and MSCs, screen printing technique could also be used to construct flexible multi-functional micro-sensors [103–106], including food inspection [107,108], environmental monitoring [109,110], composition detection [111–113], clinical diagnosis and monitoring [114–116]. Screen printed electrode stands out in the sensor due to its small size, high integration and sensitivity. Therefore, there is a growing demand for sensors to monitor a variety of environmental, physicochemical and biological parameters, which needs the rapid progress of fabricating novel sensors with advanced functions. Presently, screen printing technology is one of the most extensively investigated procedures in the production line of printed sensor. The screen-printed electrode of the sensor has become an excellent substitute, overcoming the limitations of traditional electrodes and meeting the demand for highly repeatable and reproducible and sensitive detection methods, as well as low production cost, flexible design, and small size. There are many kinds of sensors made by the screen printing process, and their inks are also diverse, typically, carbon materials [107,113,117], metal nanomaterials [118,119], oxides [120,121], and polymers [100,122]. Interestingly, adding nanomaterials or enzymes among other compounds into the ink can extend the functions or enhancing properties of the sensors. In particular, the integration of biomaterial-based responsive ink through screen printing opens up a promising way for large-scale production of responsive distributed sensing interfaces (Fig. 9 a and b) [100]. Responsive ink formulations for bioactive biomaterials consist of thickener, plasticizer, silk fibroin, and molecules such as pH indicators or enzymes (among others). The sensors of bioactive inks could reveal quantify chemicals (such as sweat and other body fluids) released by the body or its surroundings by changing color. The ink can be screen-printed in the fashion of high resolution and complex patterns on textiles such as clothes, shoes and even masks to provide detailed maps of the body's exposure and rapid response to chemicals. However, the air permeability, washability and large-scale production still remain challenges for most electronic textiles. To this end, Li et al. [101] fabricated a washable E-textile with high electrical conductivity and high air permeability, and showed its appliance as a self-powered triboelectric gesture textile (Fig. 9c-e). The E-textile can be mass-produced on ordinary fabrics and display outstanding stability after washing. In the future, this kind of electronic fabric is expected to play a more and more important role in wearable electronics, smart home, sensors, Internet of things, medical and other fields. Soft pressure sensor is one of the indispensable devices in the application of robot technology and printed microelectronics. The conductive screen-printed ink by combining PEDOT:PSS with bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide lithium salt was used to construct the capacitive sensor with pressure sensitive (Fig. 9f-h) [102]. Owing to high conductivity, PEDOT:PSS is exploited and added into ionic additive bis(trifluoromethane) sulfonimide lithium salt to ameliorate the stretchability. Besides of the ink, the substrates for screen printing are also evolving. To entirely substitute the traditional stiff or unreliable printed circuit substrates, Jerald Yoo et al. [123] recently proposed the bio-degradable medical hydrocolloid dressing (3 M Tegaderm) as the passive and interconnected platform for screen-printing wearable sensors. Screen-printed sensors were also exploited to develop robot sensors that mimic human perception. The electrochemical device with taste-sensing finger was printed on a robotic glove simulating soft skin, which could realize real-time data transmission by integrating with the wireless electronic board [107]. The “spicy” and “sour” fingers rely on carbon electrodes, and various catalytic nanomaterials could be used to modify the corresponding screen-printed carbon ink when required to achieve higher sensitivity and selectivity. With excellent flexibility and high sensitivity, skin-like pressure sensors have been extensively used in electronic skin. It is reported that the breathable pressure sensor with nanofiber membrane can be used in electronic skin to monitor human physiological signals and detect spatial pressure distribution [118]. The pressure sensor consists of poly(vinylidene fluoride) nanofiber membranes as the substrate, silver nanowires as the electrode, and thermoplastic polyurethane nanofiber membrane as the dielectric layer. For instance, Hu et al. [117] presented graphite nanoplates ink for screen printing enabled wireless sensor, which could accurately identify the content of diverse transparent liquids through machine learning technique, and illustrate the possibility of graphite nanoplates ink to print radiofrequency identification antenna and wireless sensing system for one-time use, ubiquitous wireless connections and large-scale applications of internet of things. Nowadays, the rapid spread of new SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus around the world triggered COVID-19 pandemic event. Due to the high infectivity, a speedy and onsite analysis is highly needed to curb the diffusion of COVID-19. For instance, Arduini et al. [124] developed a dependable and miniaturized electrochemical immunosensor to detect SARS-CoV-2. Screen printing electrode modified by carbon black nanomaterial together with magnetic beads was used to detect the enzymatic by-product 1-naphthol for COVID-19. The instrument data has the advantages of stable consistency, low detection limit, rapid analysis, miniaturization and portability, as well as easy to operate and non-invasive sampling, which makes the analytical tool an excellent electrochemical immunoassay method with high sensitivity for the virus detection. Besides, a stretchable integrated circuit platform has been demonstrated by screen printing eutectic gallium-indium (EGaIn) liquid alloy ink onto chemically cross-linked hydrogel substrate containing numerous hydroxyl groups [125], exhibiting outstanding mechanical robustness and no obvious resistance change even at an ultrahigh strain of 700%. Further, Shi et al. integrated screen-printed EGaIn integrated circuit and commercial sensors including electrocardiogram sensor, thermometer sensor and accelerometer on polyimine substrate [126], which could realize the effective detection of heart rate, body temperature and motion state. Therefore, screen printing technology displays wide application prospect in wearable and printed micro-sensors. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In summary, we summarize the recent advances of ink formation, typical scalable applications, and challenging perspectives of screen printing for emerging printed microelectronics. It is concluded that the screen printing is undeniably significant and in urgent demand for flexible, miniaturized and printed electronics. With the increasingly abundant application requirements, the screen printing technique is gradually developing towards the direction of multifunctional integrated microsystems, including MSCs, MBs and micro-sensors. It should be emphasized that the most crucial challenge lies in the reasonable design and fabrication of functional ink with excellent rheological properties. However, the rheological properties of functional ink are mainly determined by the solvents and binders used. To cater for the rapid requirement of different electronics applications, the ink needs appropriate viscosity by rationally choosing and deploying the solvents and binders. For the screen-printing ink, both organic ink and aqueous ink need certain special functionality to adapt for the various materials and applications. Generally, both of them are distinguished from the most central element of binders dispersing in organic solvent and water. Hence, much attention should be paid to precisely regulate the crucial properties of binders, such as superior elasticity and mechanical strength, high impact toughness, corrosion resistance, adjustable viscoelasticity, excellent thermal and chemical stability. In addition, the ink of lamellar structural materials (e.g., graphene) needs the addition of functional binder to avoid the re-accumulation and aggregation of lamellar flakes through the steric hindrance, induced by macromolecules (e.g., PC) and the electrostatic repulsion between lamellar flakes and binder molecules (e.g., CAB or CMC). However, the functional binders are still lacking to meet the requirements of printed electronics. Taking into account the eco-sustainable and environmentally development, aqueous binders, possessing the crucial merit of nontoxic and green environmentally, have been drawn considerable attention for wearable printed electronics. With the rapid progressing of printed inks, the bio-binders (e.g., chitosan), characteristic of biodegradability, biocompatibility, non-toxicity and optical transparency, are fascinating to accommodate the substrate of skin. So far, the types of binders, especially for the bio-binders are very limited, which is urgently required for printed electronics. First, the printed MBs with in-plane and stacked geometries, consisting of current collectors, cathode/anode and electrolyte in between, have been faced several challenges. One urgent challenge to realize superior electrochemical performance is the printing of current collectors. Although the expensive metal current collectors (e.g., Ag, Pt, Cu, Al) have been used for sandwich-like stacked LIMBs. However, the metal current collectors are difficult to apply for the in-plane interdigital MBs, due to the metal powder is difficult to form a stable printable ink. In addition, considering the flexibility and safety, another challenge is to explore high-safe and mechanically stable electrolytes which can avoid the leak of the liquid electrolyte and realize the desired flexibility. Screen printing of printable electrolyte membranes for all-solid-state batteries would be a good choice. Unfortunately, it is still hard to produce the printed electrolyte membrane skillfully applied for MBs. In addition, accurately achieving an adjustable areal loading for printed MBs remain unsolved. Generally, the speed and pressure of squeegee directly determined the electrode active materials loadings, which further influence the match of capacity and coulombic efficiency of printed electrodes. Hence, it is a precondition to pursue the desired electrochemical property by accurately controlling the speed and pressure of screen-printing process. Second, screen printing is still facing the challenge in the large-scale production for flexible MSCs. Typically, how to prepare printable inks with high viscosity and appropriate shear dilution is still a thorny problem. In addition, in the process of ink preparation, it is usually necessary to use inactive additives to prepare electrode materials ink, which will adversely affect their functional properties. Therefore, no addition of inactive additives and binders is still the major focus of screen printing for MSCs as well as MBs in the future. Besides, screen-printed MSCs need the help of masks to obtain electrode patterns, and it is still a challenge to produce high-precision interdigitated electrode patterns. Third, a variety of new nanomaterials have been recently introduced into the construction of screen-printed electrodes to improve the performance of the sensor, while the fabrication strategies of functional printed inks are still limited. At present, most of the studies is focused on adding modified nanomaterials into the ink to improve its detection sensitivity and develop its new functions. The use of nanomaterials is considered to be a promising strategy in the improvement of the reaction rate and sensor sensitivity. Further, screen printed electrodes are gradually being used in skin patches and integrated into electronic textiles. With the development of software for continuous monitoring, the medical and smart clothing applications of wearable sensors based on functional nanomaterials will increase significantly, and go deep into the monitoring of the overall physiological or environmental state, resulting in great demand. Consequently, the durability, safety and sensitivity of the printed electronic textiles will be one of the key issues of future research. In particular, the development of screen-printing sensors based on environmentally friendly materials will be a future focus direction. Based on the cost-effective and wide range of substrate requirements for screen printing, it is widely used in the field of wearable technology range from the clothing to skin, while how to fabricate a “green ink” is still faced a big challenge. In terms of the friendly environment, the main challenge of “green ink” lies in the matching of binders and substrates, and the flexibility and stretchability. In the case of textiles, it is necessary to be very flexible and not easy to be washed off to accommodate the human daily activities. However, most of current polymer carriers were used for clothing printing, such as thermoplastic polyurethane polymers [127] characterized by high transparency, good solubility in various organic solvents and good mechanical properties, which were served as the stretchable organic base to achieve high flexibility and stretchability. Furthermore, stretchable electroluminescent structures can be fabricated using this thermoplastic polyurethane, which can be directly printed on the textiles by screen printing technology. Meanwhile, it can be combined with the natural biocompatibility and biodegradation of biological materials to solve its safety issue. In addition, printed micro-sensors have high power consumption in detecting and recording transmission information, and most devices cannot meet the needs for wearing in a long time. Combined with printed electrochemical energy storage devices such as MBs and MSCs, a smaller and more durable power supply could be achieved by printing technique. With the development of 4D printing in recent years, screen printing may be directly printed on the substrates of smart materials in the future, realizing an intelligent design to control the printed microsystems through certain stimulants, such as water, temperature, light, and magnetism. Typically, for printed microelectronics, it might be possible to control the sensors as well as the conduction and disconnection of the micro energy storage device through the changes in body temperature and sweat secretion. In this way, the intelligent characteristics can be extended to the printed microelectronics systems to realize intelligent control and comprehensive information communications. Therefore, the screen printing is a highly promising technology for various industrially applicable printed microelectronics. coredata.dc:description: Screen printing is regarded as a highly competitive manufacture technology for scalable and fast fabrication of printed microelectronics, owing to its advanced merits of low-cost, facile operability and scalability. However, its large-scale application in printed microelectronics is still limited by screen printing functional ink. In this review, we summarize the recent advances of ink formation, typical scalable applications, and challenging perspectives of screen printing for emerging printed microelectronics. Firstly, we introduce the major mechanism of screen printing and the formation of different organic- and aqueous-based inks by various solvents and binders. Next, we review the most widely used applications of screen printing technique in micro-batteries, micro-supercapacitors and micro-sensors, demonstrative of wide applicability. Finally, the perspectives and future challenges in the sight of screen printing are briefly discussed.
